items.abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>CotG is an abundant protein initially identified as an outer component of the<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Bacillus subtilis</jats:named-content>spore coat. It has an unusual structure characterized by several repeats of positively charged amino acids that are probably the outcome of multiple rounds of gene elongation events in an ancestral minigene. CotG is not highly conserved, and its orthologues are present in only two<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Bacillus</jats:named-content>and two<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Geobacillus</jats:named-content>species. In<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">B. subtilis</jats:named-content>, CotG is the target of extensive phosphorylation by a still unidentified enzyme and has a role in the assembly of some outer coat proteins. We report now that most spore-forming bacilli contain a protein not homologous to CotG of<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">B. subtilis</jats:named-content>but sharing a central “modular” region defined by a pronounced positive charge and randomly coiled tandem repeats. Conservation of the structural features in most spore-forming bacilli suggests a relevant role for the CotG-like protein family in the structure and function of the bacterial endospore. To expand our knowledge on the role of CotG, we dissected the<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">B. subtilis</jats:named-content>protein by constructing deletion mutants that express specific regions of the protein and observed that they have different roles in the assembly of other coat proteins and in spore germination.</jats:p><jats:p><jats:bold>IMPORTANCE</jats:bold>CotG of<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">B. subtilis</jats:named-content>is not highly conserved in the<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Bacillus</jats:named-content>genus; however, a CotG-like protein with a modular structure and chemical features similar to those of CotG is common in spore-forming bacilli, at least when CotH is also present. The conservation of CotG-like features when CotH is present suggests that the two proteins act together and may have a relevant role in the structure and function of the bacterial endospore. Dissection of the modular composition of CotG of<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">B. subtilis</jats:named-content>by constructing mutants that express only some of the modules has allowed a first characterization of CotG modules and will be the basis for a more detailed functional analysis.</jats:p>
title: CotG-Like Modular Proteins Are Common among Spore-Forming Bacilli
